g.title: leaf_9
g.text: I just got orb stood up in the pylon bootloader distribution.

g.title: leaf_18
g.text: This all goes into global space for now. Our more sophisticated loader will
handle namespace isolation. Meanwhile we're building a repl, so.

g.title: leaf_26
g.text: -- #todo make this properly black and white ts
local f, err = loadstring('return ' .. chunk, 'REPL') -- first we prefix return
f, err = loadstring(chunk, 'REPL') -- try again without return
-- Lua expects some more input; stow it away for next time
-- Deprecated, but useful if I want, y'know, a REPL

g.title: leaf_37
g.text: The reader takes a stream of data from

g.title: leaf_40
g.text: processes it into tokens, which stream to the recognizer.

g.title: leaf_48
g.text: Currently the keybuf is a simple array that holds bytes until we have

g.title: leaf_50
g.text: It is cleared and reused, to avoid a glut of allocations and allow the tracer

g.title: leaf_55
g.text: Soon I'll move the remaining local state into an instance table, to make

g.title: leaf_66
g.text: -- This will be called parse_digits and be substantially more complex.
-- more like jumpwrite at this point but w/e

g.title: leaf_65
g.text: Writes will eventually happen in their own library. Right now we're building

g.title: leaf_104
g.text: -- it is possible to coerce a terminal into sending these, apparently:
local kind, col, row = byte(seq,4), byte(seq, 5), byte(seq, 6)
local shift = kind % 2 == 1 and true or false
local meta = kind % 2 == 1 and true or false
local ctrl = kind % 2 == 1 and true or false
local moving = kind % 2 == 1 and true or false
-- we skip a bit that seems to just mirror the motion
-- it may be pixel level, I can't tell and idk
local scrolling = kind == 2 and true or false
-- ^Q hard coded as quit, for now
if head <= 31 and not navigation[seq] then

g.title: leaf_105
g.text: -- Get names for as many values as possible
-- This switches screens and does a wipe,
-- Crude hack to choose raw mode at runtime

g.title: leaf_80
g.text: After flailing about and writing what was no doubt a good parser for
individual byte sequences, I discovered that

g.title: leaf_83
g.text: gives them to me a seq at a

g.title: leaf_90
g.text: So we're just going to make this a jump table that translates

g.title: leaf_98
g.text: I'm also going to switch to

g.title: leaf_103
g.text: To avoid extraneous quoting, we define the tokens as keys, and their escape
